title: UN chief urges G7 to do more on climate
text:
BIARRITZ, France — The world isn’t doing nearly enough to combat climate change, the head of the U.N. told G7 leaders Monday — just as six of those countries threw in the towel on getting U.S. President Donald Trump to change his mind on the issue.

United Nations Secretary-General António Guterres painted a dire picture of how the world is doing on getting global warming under control, less than four years after the landmark Paris Agreement was meant to signal a more aggressive approach to limiting climate change.

“We are [doing] much worse than we were during Paris,” Guterres said, in reference to negotiations to agree the climate pact that Trump abandoned shortly after taking office. Guterres wants the rise in global temperatures to be limited to the Paris Agreement’s more ambitious 1.5 degrees Celsius target in this century, for the world to aim for carbon neutrality by 2050 and for a 45 percent reduction in emissions by 2030.

“It’s absolutely essential that countries commit themselves to increase what was promised in Paris,” he said. “Because what was promised in Paris is not enough and what was promised in Paris is not even being implemented at the present moment. We need more ambition. We need a stronger commitment.”

Guterres spoke in the wake of the World Meteorological Organization finding that July was possibly the world's hottest month on record.

Trump’s lack of interest in the broad multilateral environmental agenda was on full display Monday.

But there’s little sign that the G7 will form a common front.

After years of fraught summits with Trump, this time his fellow world leaders decided it wasn’t worth fighting with him — and concluded their meeting in Biarritz without a common communiqué. The brief final declaration doesn't mention climate or the environment.

The leaders also didn't bother to dissuade Trump from his plan to drop out of the Paris Agreement.

“We know his position … and at the G7 we did not have [an] objective to convince him to return,” said French President Emmanuel Macron.

Guterres didn't single out the famously prickly Trump for criticism, instead saying he was relying on U.S. states, the American public, businesses and civil society to galvanize support for his goals.

AWOL

Trump’s lack of interest in the broad multilateral environmental agenda was on full display Monday. He was the only G7 leader not to bother turning up for a morning session devoted to climate change and the environment. Macron downplayed the significance of his absence.

“President Trump had several bilateral meetings … that meant he wasn’t in the room, but his team was there,” Macron said, adding that he spoke “at length” about the situation of the forest fires in the Amazon with Trump and “he shares the objective I have.” The G7 agreed to set up a $20 million fund to help fight the fires.

Trump explained his absence by saying he was meeting with leaders from Germany and India — both of whom were at the environment session.

During the closing G7 press conference, Trump stressed that he’s an “environmentalist” who wants “the cleanest water on Earth, the cleanest air on Earth ... I think I know more about the environment than most people.”

But he also said he wants the U.S. to cash in on its “tremendous” energy resources. “I am not going to lose that wealth on dreams, on windmills which frankly aren’t working too well.”

Macron has made the Paris Agreement a key part of his presidency's environmental policy — a point of pride for France which hosted the 2015 summit and helped pull together the final deal. France and other climate allies are investing diplomatic effort into boosting the number of countries committed to cutting emissions to net zero by mid-century, Macron said.

“Others are strengthening their commitments,” he said pointing to major polluters such as Russia, China and India.

The U.N. secretary-general is trying to drum up support for more aggressive climate action ahead of a U.N. climate summit taking place in New York on September 23. He has appointed Macron and Jamaica’s Prime Minister Andrew Holness to lead efforts to mobilize climate change financing for developing nations.

“The G7 was an excellent opportunity to appeal for a very strong engagement of the international community,” he said. “The youth have been leading the way. We will start the summit with a Youth Climate Summit in the U.N. but we need especially those countries that belong to the G7 to give a positive example.”

As an example of the damage being caused by global warming, Guterres pointed to Greenland — which Trump talked of buying last week — saying: “If one looks at Greenland, the second-largest ice cap, Greenland is melting dramatically — 179 billion tons of ice melted during the month of July.”

“I am not sure if all world leaders appreciate the magnitude of the climate crisis,” he said.

This article has been updated to include the final G7 declaration.
